COUNTRY AND URBAN TRANSPORT BACKGROUND COUNTRY ECONOMIC CONTEXT 1.1 Turkmenistan, the southernmost republic of the former Soveit Union, is bordered to the west by the Caspian Sea, to the south by Iran and Afghanistan, to the east by Tajikistan and to the north and northeast by Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan. The country gained its independence on October 27, 1991. Turkmenistan lies in the midst of two of the largest deserts in the world, the Karakum and Kyzyl Kum, and 90% of its land is considered arid. With an area of 488,000 kin2, it is the fourth largest country of the Former Soviet Union republics (FSU). 1.2 Turkmenistan is one of the least urbanized of the FSU countries with 45% of the total population in urban areas. The country's small population of 4.5 million people is concentrated in a thin strip of land along the foothills of the South and in areas where the land is irrigated. The nation's capital, Ashghabat, is the largest urban center with an estimated population of 500,000. Compared to other countries of the FSU, Turkmenistan7s health indicators are poor. Life expectancy is the lowest (63 for males and 70 for females); the infant mortality rate (IMR) is the highest (46/1,000); maternal mortality is the fifth highest; rates of cardiovascular dieseases are extremely high and increasing; and respiratory, digestive, infectious and parasitic diesease are also among the highest of any FSU countries. 1.3 Turkmenistan's economy is dominated by energy and agriculture. It has 1.3 trillion cubic meters of proven and probable natural gas reserves and is the world's fourth largest natural gas producer. It also has 1.1 billion tons of oil reserves. Despite these energy reserves, the economy is still predominantly agricultural. THE URBAN SETTING 1.4 The urban population, estimated at 1.9 million in 1994, accounts for about 45% of the total population compared to a range of 40% to 75% in FSU and 30% to 60% in the Central Asia subregion of the FSU. However, the rate of growth in the urban population has been particularly high since 1990, reflecting the increasing liberalization of economic activity, the mobility of labor, and the relatively strong growth of the service sector in urban areas. 1.5 Ashghabat, the nation's capital, is the largest urban center with an estimated population of 500,000. Since 1991, the Government has devoted much of its development budget to upgrading the city's commercial and administrative infrastructure. This expenditure has underpinned both a substantial growth in construction and commercial
 2 Chapter I activity and contributed to the rapid growth of eight per cent per annum in the city's population in the last five years. 1.6 The other major urban centers in the country are Chardjou (population of 180,000), Mary (population of 167,000), Dashkovuz (population of 140,000), Nebitag (population of 109,000) and Turkmenbashi (population of 64,000). In aggregate, the population of these towns has been stagnant since 1991. 1.7 With the exception of Ashghabat, the major urban centers are the administrative centers for the country's five local governments (velayats). Ashghabat, as the capital city, has velayat status. Funding for local services and infrastructure provided by the urban centers is derived predominantly from the central government through a system of revenue-sharing of centrally administered taxes (Value-Added Tax, income taxes and natural resources tax) and subventions from the central government. The revenue-sharing rates and the level of subventions are determined annually. Velayats can levy their own taxes and user fees and can borrow to finance services and investments. All local government budgets are subject to approval by the central government, giving it a primary role in determining the level and composition of urban services. URBAN TRANSPORT IN TURKMENISTAN 1.8 The total passenger vehicle population of Turkmenistan is estimated at 50,000 units. Detailed vehicle statistics are only available for Ashghabat, which is estimated to account for over 40% of the national public transport vehicle population, of which 90% are cars. In terms of ownership and use, about 70% of the car fleet is privately owned with the balance owned by enterprises or operated as public taxis. In contrast, only about ten percent of the bus and minivan fleet is owned privately, with the rest held by enterprises for transport of their workforces or operated by the public transport enterprise. Although private car ownership in Ashghabat has grown rapidly over the last five years, the car population, at 25 units per 1000 population or 200 units per square km, is still very small in comparison with other middle income countries. 1.9 The relatively small private car population has left a large role for public transport in meeting mobility needs in urban centers. A detailed survey of passenger transport use in Ashghabat indicates that about 55% of the city's population relies exclusively on public transport for work and social trips compared to 20% that depend exclusively on the use of private cars or enterprise transport. Given significantly lower private car ownership rates, the degree of dependence on public transport is probably substantially greater in the rest of the country. 1.10 Public transport in the urban areas is provided predominantly by a fleet of 2,000 diesel and gasoline buses operated by municipally owned enterprises managed by the Ministry of Autotransport (MoAT). INSTITUTIONAL FRAMEWORK 1.13 The Ministry of Autotransport (MoAT) is vested with responsibility for urban transport planning and regulation. The Ministry also has the responsibility for management of inter-city bus, urban bus and intercity and urban cargo transport operations. These operations are conducted through chartered (commercially autonomous) enterprises. MoAT staff have executive responsibility for the enterprises' performance, overall investment planning and financing, budgeting, route scheduling, operational management, and licensing. Fares for passenger transport are set on a national basis by the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MOF) based on submissions by the MoAT. Fares on trolleybus system are also set by central Government at the same

Investments for system expansion are the responsibility of the central government. 1.14 At the municipal level, the city governments are responsible for setting bus routes and service levels, constructing and maintaining stops, overseeing service quality and financing losses incurred by the MoAT's municipal public passenger transport operations. The financing needs of urban bus transport operations are established annually in advance through an operational budgeting exercise. The operational budgets provide for bus replacement financing needs through depreciation charges while the financing of system expansion is the responsibility of the central government. Investments for expansion of municipal bus systems are established under the state's annual development budget. 1.15 The municipalities are also responsible, in principle, for overall planning of land use and infrastructural facilities (roads, traffic, utilities, etc), the preparation of master plans for the future investments in urban infrastructure and services, scheduling, and coordination of all public transport services and road maintenance. In practice, only Ashghabat has developed the institutions (Agency for Roads Management and Department of Planning and Architecture) to perform these services. Other municipalities have effectively redelegated these responsibilities to the central government. 1.16 The licensing of private passenger transport operators in all municipalities is currently the responsibility of the MoAT. The fares charged by private urban passenger transport operators were decontrolled with effect from December, 1995. 1.17 The Ministry of Interior is responsible for the formulation and implementation of traffic laws in all urban areas. The Ministry is also responsible for the operation of traffic signals and road safety in all cities. 1.18 The prevailing institutional arrangements for the delivery of urban public transport services have a number of serious shortcomings: (a) Fragmentation of Responsibilities. The division of responsibility for the operational and financial performance of the bus systems increases the complexity of managing such systems. More importantly, the fragmentation of responsibilities for the systems has diffused accountability for their performance. While municipalities have responsibility for any residual financing requirements of the system, they have neither the powers nor the capacity to exercise effective oversight of the MoAT's operational management. Similarly, the MoAT is compelled to continue to provide services irrespective of the payment of subsidy obligations by the cities. In practice, the municipalities have abdicated most responsibility for oversight of the bus system for two reasons: (i) owing to staffing constraints, they have been unable to assess and thus control the efficiency with which bus services are provided; and (b) they
 Chapter I 5 have not been able to finance the full recurrent subsidies required by the bus systems, at current efficiency levels, to operate at agreed service levels. In Ashghabat, there is no effective formal mechanism for co- ordination of the operations and investment planning for the bus and trolleybus systems. Most of the co-ordination of the services operations is currently based on informal but strong ties between the management of the systems; (b) Commingling of Regulatory and Functional Roles. The regulatory and policy roles of the MoAT are commingled with its direct operating responsibilities for the dominant segment of urban passenger transport. This creates potential conflicts of interest in the development of appropriate public policy and, given the limited staff of MoAT, serves to dilute its effectiveness in both operational management and policy making; (c) Inadequate Incentives for Monitoring of Performance Standards. Under the present institutional arrangements, the regulating and supervisory agencies (MoAT, the municipalities and the MOF) bear little of the financial burden arising from their decisions. At the same time, public transport operators are not held accountable for defined standards of operating efficiency. This absence of mutual accountability for performance has fostered a climate of poor performance; (d) Difusion of Management Capability. The MoAT has a number of diverse operating responsibilities. Its operation of urban taxi services is peripheral to the main public objective of providing mass transport services and results in diverting both managerial and public investment resources from the provision of bus services, used by a majority of the population. Its extensive involvement in inter-urban bus and cargo services as well as intra-urban cargo services further stretches its capacity; and (e) Erosion of Financial Performance. The operating subsidy requirements of public transport has grown substantially since 1991 as fares have been subject to tight regulatory restraint, while operating costs, particularly spare parts, have increased significantly. Cost increases have taken place as traditional managed trade relations between the COMECON countries and the FSU, and within the FSU, have been replaced by market-based * relations and prices. Municipal budgetary support to public transport has not grown correspondingly to cover the ensuing financing gap, forcing MoAT to partly cross-subsidize bus operations by its other relatively cash- generative transport operations and to partly curtail maintenance of the fleet. Vehicle replacement rates have been similarly constrained by a lack of funds. Recent bus replacement investments have reflected barter opportunities rather than programmed purchases. Under these

GOVERNMENT'S URBAN TRANSPORT STRATEGY IN SECTOR 1.19 The Government recognizes the need for substantial changes to the framework within which public transport services are provided in the urban areas. Since the commencement of an active dialogue with the Bank on the sector, the Government has adopted a reform program for the sector designed to: (a) establish a framework for the efficient and cost-effective performance of public sector transport operations; (b) provide a stable and adequate level of funding to ensure the sustainability of efficient service provision by the public sector; and (c) reduce the fiscal burden on the public sector by promoting private sector involvement in the provision of public transport. 1.20 The reform program as presented in the Government's Policy Statement (June 1996) included the following key measures (Annex 1.1): (a) consolidation of managerial responsibility for all public sector passenger transport operations in each municipality under one autonomous agency accountable to the municipal government; (b) institution of explicit operating and financial performance objectives for transport agencies by the municipal governments under annual contracts for delivery of specified services; (c) determination of the annual subsidy requirements of the agencies in advance based on budgets embodying the agreed performance objectives; (d) allocation of each municipality's agreed subsidy requirement in the central government budget annually in advance coupled with adequate measures to supplement budgetary allocations to take account of increases in operating costs that are not compensated by increases in fares; (e) a progressive increase in fares for public transport services provided by the municipalities to a level sufficient to cover the full cash costs of operating the services; and (f) the expansion of private participation in the provision of public transport services through the abolition of regulatory restrictions on the provision of taxi and minivan services, the leasing of minivans currently owned and operated by the public sector to private operators, the encouragement of participation by private operators in the provision of services in selected areas of municipalities under contractual agreements with the municipalities, and the liberalization of fares for all private sector transport operations except for contracted services with the municipalities.

The key elements of the reform program implemented by the Government over the past year include: (a) A Presidential Decree, requiring the municipalities to assume responsibility for all mass public sector transport operations in their jurisdiction was introduced in March 1996; (b) The Government has established an Ashghabat Passenger Autotransport Production Organization (APAPO) designed to introduce and implement improved systems and practices to the management of all aspects of urban transport operations in Ashghabat. The organization is headed by a Director-General and other key positions in the management group are in place. The office space for APAPO has been identified; (c) An OIP has been prepared and is under implementation in the city of Ashghabat. The successful implementation of OIP would lay the groundwork for effective utilization of the significant bus replacement investment program planned for the city; (d) The Government is implementing its reform program to improve cost recovery. The bus fares have gradually increased from 0.05 manats per trip in January 1995 to 50 manats in December 1996. This increase in fares is significantly above the rate of devaluation in the domestic currency; (e) The private participation in the provision of public transport services has expanded through: (a) abolition of regulatory restrictions on the provision of taxi and minivan services; (b) the leasing of minivans currently owned by the public sector to private operations; and (c) the liberalization of fares for all private sector transport operations except for contracted services with the municipalities. More recently, a Presidential Decree, requiring privatization of a part of the public taxi fleet through open auctions, organized by the State Commodity and Raw Materials Exchange of Turkmenistan was introduced on July 1, 1996; and (f) APAPO has initiated the Social Assessment to create a foundation for the involvement of citizens in providing inputs to transport policy and contribute to policy dialogue.
 8 Chapter I URBAN TRANSPORT AND THE ENVIRONMENT 1.23 Energy consumption and emissions from vehicles are high in former Soviet Union countries compared to Western European and North American standards, particularly carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrocarbons (HC). Not only were domestic vehicles produced without catalytic converters and basics like electronic ignition and exhaust-gas recirculation, but also there was the widespread use of gasoline rather than diesel fueled heavy vehicles and buses. About 45 percent of the urban bus fleet in Ashghabat is still powered by gasoline rather than less polluting and more fuel-efficient diesel-powered engines. 1.24 Reductions in CO, HC and Pb emissions can be made by changing the composition of the vehicle fleet. The project will improve air quality in the project cities because of the replacement of gasoline-powered buses by diesel-powered ones, rehabilitation and improved maintenance of the bus fleet. 1.25 The proposed project will not generate activities that create significant new or additional environmental impact. The objective of the project is to stabilize public transport capacity and restore public transport passenger spaces lost due to past and continuing attrition within the bus and trolleybus fleets. The project does not create new capacity nor increase fleet sizes beyond previous limits. The impact of the project on public transport vehicle emission levels will be moderately beneficial (paras 4.53-4. 54). 1.26 Draft legislation for environmental legislation and emission standards for Turkmenistan has been reviewed during project preparation and the proposed project does not conflict with the draft legislation. RATIONALE FOR BANK INVOLVEMENT 1.27 The role of the Bank in the sector is essentially twofold. First, drawing upon its international and regional experience, the Bank is in a strong position to support the Government in formulating the strategies necessary to ensure that an adequate, efficient and sustainable level of public transport services is available to the urban population. Second, the Bank can assist the Government in implementing these strategies through both the finaticing of technical advice, training and investments and direct analytical support to the Govermment during implementation. The proposed project would also be important for the implementation of key reforms, not only in the urban transport sector, but also in other areas of the public sector, by demonstrating the effectiveness of such reforms. 1.28 A first Bank Group Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) has been prepared, at the request of the Government, for discussion by the Board, together with this Operation. The proposed project is consistent with that CAS. Specifically, the strategies for reorganization, financing, and regulation of urban transport services that the Government has adopted, following close dialogue and collaboration with the Bank, would help

 2. THE URBAN TRANSPORT SUBSECTOR IN ASHGHABAT TRANSPORT SUPPLY CHARACTERISTICS 2.1 Mass public transport services are provided by diesel bus and trolleybus enterprises. The composition of the bus and trolley fleet is summarized in Annex 2.1. 2.2 The total bus fleet in November 1996 was 195 buses (68 Ikarus, 76 Laz, 50 Sahab, and 1 Karosa). Since April 1996, 21 Ikarus buses have been scrapped and removed from the books and 12 Laz buses have been transferred to other towns. Eighteen buses are long-term defective, awaiting engines and can be rehabilitated and returned to service. In addition, 34 buses are in workshop for various short-term defects. On average, only 55% of the total vehicle fleet is available for service at any time. The low availability of the bus fleet reflects two factors. First, the LAZ buses, comprising 40% of the fleet have unfavorable design features, are prone to a high rate of failure and require intensive maintenance. Second, the bus enterprise has encountered great problems in obtaining the financing to import and hold an inventory of spare parts necessary to ensure the adequate maintenance of the total fleet of buses at an acceptable level of availability. One adverse consequence of the attendant deferral of maintenance of the fleet has been a significant acceleration in the deterioration of the mechanical condition of the fleet and the shortening in the operating life of buses. The usual practice has been to cannibalize buses out of service. At present, buses are operated for six to seven years as compared to an assessed operating life of adequately maintained buses, in similar climatic and road conditions, of 10 to 15 years. 2.3 The trolleybus fleet has also experienced similar maintenance and availability problems. Out of a total of 63 trolleybuses in 1996, six trolleybuses (with an average age greater than 10 years) are life expired and cannibalized to the extent that only shells remain. Twelve trolleybuses are over five years old and due to shortage of funds, have not undergone the capital repair program required at the mid-life point for trolleybuses. At present, only 70% of the vehicle fleet is available for service. Over the past five years, the vehicle fleet has been reduced by 18%. 2.4 The bus enterprise also operates a fleet of minibuses, minivans and taxis. The minibus fleet of 134 vehicles consists of 101 buses purchased in 1994 and 33 Mercedes purchased in 1995, under barter arrangements with Iran. While the vehicles represent a further diversification of vehicle model and spare parts requirement in the fleet of the enterprise, no provisions were made for after-sale service facilities or support. After an initial period of high reliability in service, the minibus fleet has already started to experience increasing mechanical problems and declining availability as a result of the enterprise's inability to perform scheduled maintenance and services and the poor quality

A number of measures have been taken by the Government over the past eighteen months to privatize operations of minivans and taxis (paras 2.28-2.30). 2.5 The bus enterprise controls a fleet of about 1,000 taxis consisting predominantly of Volgas with an average age of 10 years. A significant addition was made to the fleet in 1994 with the purchase of 100 cars from Turkey. Vehicles in the fleet are operated by the enterprise for 450,000 km, after which they are leased to the drivers or set aside. Lease terms provide for the maintenance of the vehicle by the enterprise. Currently, about 60% of the taxi fleet is operational and about 50% of the operational fleet is operated on a lease-basis. 2.6 The RAF minivan fleet consists of 59 vehicles purchased in 1993. Beginning March 1996, all minivans are leased out to private operators for unrestricted use within the city. 2.7 The provision of privately owned and operated public transport services, although growing, is limited. The Government formally liberalized entry into public passenger transport in December 1994, with the eligibility to operate subject to a simple licensing and registration process. However, only a small proportion of vehicles has been licensed. Nonetheless, there is a vigorous informal and unlicensed private provision of passenger services. In particular, private cars and enterprises' own transport play a growing and visible role in the. city's transport supply. Enterprise taxis and private cars have increased significantly between 1993 and 1994, with private cars increasing from 30,997 in 1993 to 34,652 in 1994 (growth rate of 11 percent) and enterprise taxis increasing from 768 to 1,210 (over 50 percent growth rate) for the same time period. 2.8 Performance Measures of Public Transport Operations. There are 29 diesel- bus, 7 trolleybus, and 20 minibus routes in the city. The public transport system, as currently structured and operated, suffers from a number of deficiencies: (a) Network Coverage. While the network coverage of the city is generally good, it leaves significant segments of the city partially or completely unserved. The most prominent unserved area is the northeast which is also the part of the city with the lowest household income. (b) Overlapping Services. The overlap in routes served by the three public transport systems (diesel bus, trolleybus, and minibus) is excessive and leads to significant competition rather than complementary in the provision of services. The resulting congestion of services along some routes penalizes service quality in other routes while tying up capacity which could otherwise be allocated to underserved or high demand zones. . (c) Overlapping routes. The incidence of overlapping routes operated by the same system is high. This has led to an inefficient allocation of capacity on some routes, as well as excessive traffic on other routes, irregularity of service, and undue congestion at bus stops.
 Chapter 11 13 (d) Long Routes. Bus and minibus routes are extremely long for urban services catering to passengers with an average trip length of about 2 km. This leads to long trips for passengers as well as lower than attainable frequency of bus arrivals. (e) Service Unreliability. Owing to frequent vehicle failures and weak operational planning and control of crews and vehicles, there are frequent and abrupt interruptions of service and the punctuality of service is highly variable. In particular, bus service quality varies with the time-of-the-day and the day-of-the-week. The highest bus frequencies are available during the weekday morning peak period and lower during the afternoon peak-period. The frequency of bus arrivals tapers off as the day progresses and is lowest during the weekends. In addition, bus drivers often take detours to satisfy individual travelers willing to pay higher fares. The unreliability of public transport services often forces people to take the more expensive private modes. TRANSPORT DEMAND CHARACTERISTICS SOCIAL ASSESSMENT 2.9 Background. A social assessment (SA) was conducted in February 1995, as part of the identification process for the proposed urban transport project in Turkmenistan. The study was conducted in the capital city of Ashghabat, and focused on various aspects of demand and supply of public and private transportation, various stakeholder groups (households, transport users, bus drivers, drivers of private vehicles and bus and trolleybus enterprises). It also incorporated results of discussions with the public transport agency and the municipality. (Annex 2.2) 2.10 Objectives. The overall objective of the SA was to provide a better understanding of the transport use patterns and needs in Ashghabat. Public policy objective in setting bus and trolleybus fares is to ensure that public transport is accessible to all segments of the population. Up until June 1995, the fares for buses and trolleybuses were set at 0.05 manats per trip, leading to a significant erosion in their real value when compared to inflation of about 25% over the same period. More graphically, by June 1995, the value of bus fare per trip had been eroded to the point where it was equal to the cost of printing a ticket. 2.18 In principle, the rigid control of public transport fares was meant to ensure that public transport was affordable to all segments of the population. No efforts were made in the past to evaluate if the residents could afford to pay higher fare for a better and more reliable service or even what they were actually paying to satisfy their daily transport requirements. In .practice, low fares led to: (a) a severe squeeze in the operating margin of operators which was not compensated by operating subsidies from the municipality or the Government; (b) a sharp deterioration in service quality; and (c) increasing diversion of the population to other emerging and more expensive modes, primarily informal taxis. The adverse side-effects of the bus fares policy on the effective cost of public transport was exacerbated by two other factors: (a) the high rates of inflation led to a progressive withdrawal of the low denomination 0.05 manat coins from circulation, forcing many passengers to use higher denomination (2 manat) currency for the 0.05 manat fare; and (b) households demonstrated willingness to pay substantially in excess of regulated fares, coupled with poor supervisory control over bus drivers, provided strong incentives for drivers to charge in excess of officially set fares, for personal gains. Often, the drivers charged arbitrary fares (especially during off-peak period) giving riders the choice to either pay or get off. Finally, monthly passes, which at 5 manats per month offered potentially substantial discounts on the official fares to frequent users, became increasingly unattractive as the predictability of the bus and trolleybus services deteriorated. 2.19 The findings of the Social Assessment demonstrated the ineffectiveness of the fares policy as an instrument for ensuring the affordability of public transport. The majority (70%) of users were paying about 2.0 manats per trip using public transport while the average cost of trips for cash paying respondents was about 3.2 manats for transport, including taxis and minivans (as against the official fare of 0.05 manat per trip for public transport). In addition, as almost 65 percent of the respondents were required to change mode at least once to complete a trip, the average actual fare paid for one trip was increased to about 5 manat. 2.20 Cost Recovery. LESSONS OF EXPERIENCE 3.1 Since 1972, the World Bank has funded over thirty urban transport projects and an even larger number of urban development projects with a substantial urban transport component. These projects have been quite diversified in terms of content, countries, and circumstances under which they have been designed and implemented. The major objective of World Bank lending for urban transport has been to improve and extend available facilities and services through the use of low cost options. For this reason, the greatest emphasis has been placed on: (a) rationalization of the use of urban transport facilities, particularly urban roads; (b) provision of better access through upgrading and extension of the road networks; and (c) improvement in the standards and viability of public transport services. A more general objective has been to meet the special needs of the urban poor. Upgrading and extending road networks in low income neighborhoods has also been a priority, as well as improving the public transport services benefiting the poor. Other objectives of World Bank urban transport operations have been to improve planning and coordination and to better integrate urban transport with urban development. More recently, Bank objectives have focused on the privatization of urban transport, including contracting out maintenance and other services, but most of the projects incorporating these objectives are ongoing projects. 3.2 With few exceptions, physical components of urban transport projects were generally implemented as planned. While some changes did take place and some components were poorly planned, the physical components proposed at appraisal proved to be feasible and supported by decision makers. Overall estimated project costs were also of the right order, although wide variations in individual components occurred. 3.3 Transport policy measures were included in some, but not all projects, with mixed results. A number of projects (Bombay, Madras, Cote d'Ivoire and Calcutta) invested in public bus or monopoly bus operations (often supplying buses). Except in Calcutta, all the companies were relatively efficient with, for example, availability of the fleet of the order of 90 percent and reasonable staffing ratios. All companies made operational improvements during project implementation. Nevertheless, governments were reluctant to allow bus fares to rise adequately to meet agreed revenue/cost ratios (covenanted under the loans) and for financial targets to be met, demonstrating the political difficulties of raising fares. 3.4 Project schedules were chronically over-optimistic at appraisal, due to: (a) difficulties of implementing traffic schemes; (b) failure to complete final designs in a timely manner; (G) unfamiliarity with World Bank procedures (especially procurement); and (d) lack of counterpart funds.

At present, responsibility for regulating and providing services in the urban transit sector is shared by several organizations, which results in poor service and redundancy. A transport demand model was developed and calibrated for estimating passenger transport demand for 1995 which was used to predict travel demand for year 2000. The model area included the urbanized area of Ashghabat (including suburban areas), which was divided into 25 zones. The road network was represented by links, centroids, and zones. The links connect the centroids and zones and used for movement of pedestrians and vehicles. Three types of links have been identified: main road, secondary road, and service or local roads. The centroids represent the meeting point of different links. The zones are trip production and attraction areas, and are connected to the public transport network by means of a "dummy" network to be used by pedestrian traffic. The model is developed for three public transport systems (bus, trolley bus, and mini bus) and the variables specified include: line number, direction, service type, headway, seating capacity, and crush capacity. The model is simulated for peak period traffic (6:30 am to 9:30 am) and divided into four components: trip production and attraction, distribution, modal split, and assignment. 9. Trip Generation. The basic information is collected for population, jobs, and land use patterns for each of the 25 traffic zones. It is assumed that 20 percent of the population lives and works in the same traffic zone (based on socio-economic surveys) and the trips are mainly by walking which are excluded from the model. Of the balance 80 percent, about 60 percent use public transport services for commuting. The work trips produced by each of the region was assumed to be proportional to the population. A social assessment (SA) was conducted in February 1995 as part of the identification process for a proposed urban transport project for the city of Ashghabat, Turkmenistan. It focused on aspects of demand for and supply of public and private transportation, concentrating on various stakeholder groups: households, transport users, bus drivers, drivers of private vehicles and enterprises. It also incorporated results of discussions with the public transport agency and the municipality. 2. Currently, Ashghabat's publicly managed transport system suffers from low vehicle utilization, short operating life spans, weak institutional arrangement and management, poor cost recovery, and an inadequate road network infrastructure. The purpose of the World Bank project is to improve urban transportation in Ashghabat so that it operates efficiently, effectively and sustainably. 3. The SA aimed to provide a better understanding of the uses people make of urban transport, their choices, behavior and needs. It also focused on the behavior of some transport suppliers in an attempt to identify incentives to improve their performance. The specific objectives of the social assessment are to: evaluate the social impact of the proposed World Bank project components on households and investigate how certain social groups may be affected; * help identify the most critical interventions to be undertaken immediately to improve urban transport in Ashghabat; and * ensure that project objectives and incentives for change are appropriate and acceptable to all beneficiaries, particularly low income groups. 4. The SA is basically a mechanism to allow consideration of the needs and expectations of the people potentially affected by a development intervention-urban transportation in the case of this project. Its recommendations stand alone and should be reviewed on the basis of economic, financial and technical considerations. Not all needs expressed by actual and potential users of urban transportation can meet economic and technical considerations. Similarly,, what may appear technically and economically feasible or desirable may not meet people's needs and expectations. A SA is not a substitute for other types of assessments essential for good project design and implementation, but it is a key input to such a process. It is also a good tool to facilitate participation of stakeholders in development projects. The SA process should be continued during implementation in order to provide guidance on whether the project is achieving its objectives or what modifications should be considered.
 84 Annex 2.2 5. The assessment presented here aimed at a systematic, rapid and cost-effective output, and thus combined several methodologies within the short phase of project preparation. Performed jointly by a team of social scientists from the World Bank and local experts, it comprised the following elements: * A household survey, administered to about 600 households randomly selected from the city's 16 districts ("micro-rayons") and focusing on demographic, socio- economic, employment, income and travel patterns. A stakeholder workshop was held to share preliminary survey results with the academic community, the representatives of the Ministry of Transport and the municipality. By then it was clear that the findings of the SA had been taken on board locally; a number of significant reforms in public transport management had been implemented within a month of the SA.  ANNEX 5.2 FINANCIAL EVALUATION ASSUMPTION 1. The following assumptions are the basis for the projections utilized in the financial evaluation in Chapter 5. The assumptions are consistent with those used for the economic analysis (Chapter 6). 2. Monetary Unit: US dollars. 3. Exchange Rate: All investments are expressed in US dollar terms. Historic operating costs and other balance sheet items, denominated in US dollars, have been converted at the average US$:Manat exchange rates for the relevant period. All projections are on the basis of a nominal exchange rage of US$1 = 5,000 manats. 4. Inflation Indices: Cost estimates are based on 1996 prices. Prices of imported and importable goods and services, purchased under the project, are escalated at the Bank's muv index. The cost of international non-tradeable goods and services are escalated at an average annual rate of 25% over the project implementation period. The projections are in constant (1996) US dollars. 5. Vehicle Operating Inputs. For the base year, the following assumptions were used: (a) 55 percent of the total diesel-bus fleet, 70 percent of trolleybus and 60 percent of minibuses are available for use; (b) five percent of daily mileage is non-revenue earning (dead mileage); (c) on average, vehicles operate for eight hours daily; (d) passenger carrying-kilometer is, on average, 80 percent for diesel bus, 95 percent for trolleybus and 95 percent for minibus; and (e) average trip lengths are 5.2, 3.3 and 10 kilometers for bus, trolleybus and minibus, respectively. 6. Tariffs. Bus, trolleybus and minibus tariffs are based on the current fare of 50 manats per ride for each vehicle. No price escalation is applied. 7. Operating Costs. The incremental operating costs under the project are fuel, tire and maintenance costs. On average, fuel efficiency is 3 kilometers per liter. The life of a bus tire is 55,000 kilometers and 50,000 kilometers for trolleybuses and minibuses. Annual maintenance costs are assumed to be US$2,000 per bus and per trolleybus and US$1,000 per minibus. The project includes US$1.0 million for incremental operating expenses, to be funded by the transport enterprises. Labor requirements for the rehabilitation and maintenance of the vehicles are not considered incremental as they will be performed "in-house".
 128 Annex 5.2 8. Other Costs. In March 1997, salaries and wages in Turkmenistan have doubled for all public enterprises except for selected transport sector companies, including the bus, trolleybus and minibus companies. Wages are expected to increase in the near term, however, the magnitude and timing of the correction is uncertain. The financial mode assumes that wages will increase in average of 50% for each transport companies in the base year and remain constant over the project implementation period. Overhead expenses are assumed to be about 15% of operating and employee expenses. 9. Depreciation. The depreciation schedule was determined based on current practice for the class of fixed asset. Depreciation expense was not included in discussions of cost recovery targets.

 ANNEX 6.1 ECONOMIC EVALUATION OF THE PROJECT A. Basic Methodology Used in the Evaluation 1. Underfunding of the investment and operating needs of public transport vehicles over the past few years has resulted in reduced operating lives of dieselbuses and trolleybuses and accumulation of a substantial backlog of maintenance and vehicle replacement requirements. The reduction in public transport capacity is especially alarming when viewed in the light of an average annual population growth of eight percent in Ashghabat. If efforts are not undertaken to rehabilitate bus fleet, the bus garage may effectively have to close down in the next three to four years. Over the past few years, the government has augmented the capacity of public vehicle fleet through procurement of a large number of new buses without any efforts to rehabilitate existing vehicle fleet. The investments by the Government have been sub-optimal as reflected in the purchase of sub-standard buses and the new acquisition has not made up for the attrition in the capacity of the core bus and trolleybus fleet. The proposed project attempts to assess the shortfall in supply relative to demand in the base year and estimates additional vehicle requirements in future years to satisfy projected demand. 2. The objective of the project is to improve the bus transport (dieselbus, trolleybus, and minibus) service in Ashghabat in terms of: (a) quality of service, by reducing waiting time and crowding while increasing service reliability; (b) quantity of service, by satisfying the increasing demand reflecting an expected eight percent annual population growth in Ashghabat in the medium term plus the pent-up demand in currently under- and unserved areas in Ashghabat; and (c) efficiency, by reducing transport unit costs through an integrated and balanced program of maintenance, rehabilitation and acquisition of buses supported by a broad program to eliminate specific shortcomings and weaknesses identified in different operational areas. 3. It is against this background that the proposed project includes the following three components for which an economic analysis has been undertaken:
 136 Annex 6.1 (a) Component 1. Operations Improvement Plan (OIP). Technical Assistance to* strengthen institutional and financial capacity of public transport operators and to implement an operations improvement, plan (OIP). The OIP includes preparation of optimal routing plans, driving training and control, vehicle maintenance practices, services standards, service monitoring, and bus and trolleybus terminal management; (b) Component 2. Maintenance and Rehabilitation. Upgrading maintenance facilities and equipment, rehabilitation and refurbishment of dieselbus, trolleybus, and mini bus facilities. This includes procurement of parts needed for major repairs and rehabilitation, spare parts and tires, and tools and equipment for garages. The purpose of these investments would be to provide the spare parts necessary to put back into operation the vehicle fleet currently out of service and augment the capacity of garages to provide periodic maintenance; and (c) Component 3. Purchase of New Buses. Purchase of new diesel and trolleybuses to improve service delivery, extend transport services to currently unserved outlying areas, and set in place new procurement procedures as established by Bank guidelines to ensure efficient delivery of vehicles in future. 4. Methodology. The economic benefits resulting from investments in each of the three modes (dieselbus, trolleybus, and minibus) are determined by comparing the "with" case with the "without" case. The benefits have been calculated for: (a) investments in all three components for each of the modes; and (b) investments in OIP and maintenance and rehabilitation program (excluding capital cost of new purchases). The "without" project case reflects the strategy that in the future unserviceable buses will be promptly replaced by Government on an annual basis, a strategy that Government has been following in the past few years. A major difference in the "without" case would be that Government would continue to make sub-optimal purchases of new vehicle fleet based on its ability to barter vehicles for natural gas or petroleum products. As a result, serviceability of vehicles would continue to be low. In addition, in the "without" case, vehicle availability would be low becasues of poor operational practices, fragmented institutional responsibilities, weak fiscal base, and inadequate maintenance. In the "with" case, because of institutional reforms, implementation of OIP, rehabilitation of vehicles, and emphasis on cost recovery, it would be possible to improve serviceability ratio and operating environment, resulting in availability of a larger vehicle fleet on any day operating efficiently, which would result in improved speed, lower waiting time, and better access for all residents of the city. The proposed project would rehabilitate a large number of existing bus fleet, improving their operating life from existing five to six years to about twelve years. The benefits would translate into time savings for the commuting public and evolve a mode choice in favor of public transport. The cost to make this possible would include: technical assistance; investments in spare parts, workshop, tools
 Annex 6.1 137 and equipment; incremental operating cost; and investments in purchase of additional vehicles. Data and Assumptions. Estimates of passenger demand in Ashghabat by different transport modes are obtained from household survey and on-board user surveys, conducted as part of the Social Assessment. Estimates of service characteristics, vehicle inventory and replacement and maintenance schedule have been obtained from the respective operating agencies. The key assumptions made in the computation of economic benefits are: * Operating ratio. The current operating ratio for dieselbuses is 55%; for trolleybuses is 70%; and for mini buses is 70%. The investments under the project would improve operating ratio for dieselbuses to 85%; for trolleybuses to 90%; and for mini buses to 85%. * Vehicle Rehabilitation. The project will include rehabilitation of 81 buses, 34 trolleybuses, and 33 minibuses. The Bank loan will finance the spare parts for the rehabilitation of 60 Ikarus buses (US$1.5 million, at an average cost of US$25,000 per bus) and 34 trolley buses (US$1.02 million, at an average cost of US$30,000 per trolleybus). For minibuses, the Bank loan will finance spare parts for (a) a program of modification for 101 Iveco minibuses (US$.27 million, at an average cost of US$2,700 per bus) to increase their
 138 Annex 6.1 operational life to nine years, and (b) rehabilitation of 33 minibuses (US$.33 million, at an average cost of US$10,000 per bus). The Government will finance for the rehabilitation of 21 Laz buses (US$0.32 million, at an average cost of US$15,000 per bus) and for labor and utilities costs of US$0.19 million * Service Life. Average service life for a dieselbus and trolleybus is expected to increase to 12 years from the present six years, and for minibus to nine years; * Vehicle Price. The project includes purchase of 52 twelve meter diesel buses (at an estimated cost of US$120,000 per bus), 10 dual fuel buses (at an estimated cost of US$135,000 per bus), and 40 twelve meter trolleybuses (at an estimated cost of US$160,000 per trolleybus); * Vehicle Operating Cost (VOC). VOC per vehicle-km is computed by assuming fuel efficiency of 3km/lt without, increasing to 4km/It with the project (at a cost of US$.10 per It); tire life of 50,000 km; veh-km/day at 190 km without and 205 km with the project. * Travel Demand Passenger travel demand for dieselbus in 1996 is 80 million trips; for trolleybus 25 million trips; and for mini bus 16 million trips. * Value of Time. Value of time has been calculated at 35 percent of average salary of US$700. * Travel Demand Growth. Travel demand is expected to grow at 8 percent per annum in the medium term. e Service Characteristics. The implementation of OIP is expected to increase travel speed from existing 16kph to 20kph, increase frequency from 3.0 to 4.0 during peak periods. Average trip length is 5.2 km and assumed to remain the same in future. N NPV Calculations. The NPV is computed at 12% rate of return. Project Costs. The project costs include: (a) technical assistance. The technical assistance component, at an estimated cost of US$1.8 million (including US$0.3 million for the establishment of Project Management Group), will help implement OIP, assist PMG with the implementation of the project and the procurement of goods and services, assist APAPO with the introduction of improved systems and practices for management of all aspects of urban transport operations in the participating cities, and assist municipal government and Ministry of Road Transport to further reforms in the urban transport sector . The economic analysis for each of the three modes is based on the assumption that about 70 percent of the TA is for dieselbuses and 15 percent each for trolleybuses and minibuses. (b) Maintenance and Rehabilitation. The base cost of this component includes: US$1.6 million for equipment, tools and parts to rehabilitate 81 buses, US$1.1 million to rehabilitate 34 trolleybuses, and US$0.6 million to rehabilitate 33 minibuses; US$2.1 million for spare parts, workshop, computers and other tools and equipment for diesel buses, US$1.8 million for trolley buses, and US$1.1 million for minibuses. In addition US$2.0 million is estimated for implementing OIP which would include improving vehicle monitoring and fare collection system. (c) incremental operating cost.
 Annex 6.1 139 The cost of oprerating additional vehicle fleet with the project is estimated at US$1.0 million. The calculation of incremental operating cost includes power costs, tire costs, and maintainence cost. (d) purchase of new buses. The project includes the purchase of 52 twelve meter diesel buses and 10 dual fuel buses (US$7.6 million) and 40 twelve meter trolleybuses (US$6.4 million). 5. Benefits and Returns. The benefits of the proposed investments are computed in terms of savings in trip time resulting from higher speed, lower waiting times, improved headways, and easier access to public transport because of the availability of a greater number of vehicles operating at higher efficiency as compared to without project case. Table below shows the economic rate of return for each of the three modes (both with and without investments in purchase of new fleet). Tables 1 to 3 provide details on computation of economic return. On average, without the project, there would be 135 dieselbuses, 59 trolleybuses, and 80 minibuses available for service on any particular day; in contrast, because of policy reforms and improved operating and service environment, the vehicles available with the project would increase to: 208 dieselbuses, 76 trolleybuses, and 114 minibuses. As a result of availability of a greater number of vehicles, it would be possible to improve performance on existing routes as well as extend service to currently unserved areas, which are predominantly occupied by lower income groups. The rate of return is computed for two cases for each of the three modes: (a) the total investments in the public transport system, including purchase of new vehicles; and (b) investments for each enterprise, excluding capital cost of new purchases. The costs here include the investments required to prepare and implement OIP (including technical assistance), build up an inventory of spare parts, and for rehabilitation of vehicles. 6. The rate of return for the project (including purchase of new vehicle fleet) is considerable, although, as expected, the returns increase significantly when the capital cost of new vehicles is excluded. The returns from implementation of OIP, technical assistance, and rehabilitation of vehicles (extending vehicle life from existing six years to twelve year) exceed 50 percent. However, eventually new equipment will have to be purchased. The most significant benefit of new vehicles is the inducement it has given the Government to undertake key reforms in urban transport, the benefit of which will extend far longer than the life of the project. The most critical variable in this project is that institutional and cost recovery reforms will not be implemented as promised. If these reforms are not implemented, availability rates of new buses would again start declining beyond two years because of the lack of spare parts and fleet replacement, and spare parts would once again decline because of the aging fleet--a decrease by more than 15 percent in the availability of resources for spare parts and maintenance beyond the initial two years will make the NPV negative, if other things remain as expected. The next critical variable is the timely implementation of OIP. A delay in implementation of OIP sufficient to reduce vehicle availability by more than 25 percent will make the NPV negative. The analysis also indicates that the assumed annual eight percent growth in passenger demand is not critical to the success of the project--even if annual demand grows by two-and-a-half percent, the investments will yield positive return. The per capita income would have to decrease by more than 35 percent for the savings in time to be exceeded by the proposed size of investments. 9. Other Benefits. The project will result in a number of other benefits, difficult to quantify. First, improvement in institutional arrangements will enhance efficiency of public transport enterprises in providing transport services. Second, the project, through improved cost recovery, will reduce subsidies to public transport enterprise, which at
 Annex 6.1 141 present pose a severe burden on city finances. Third, the project puts in place rational procurement policies and procedures for acquisition of new buses and spare parts. Fourth, the project supports the creation of an enabling environment for active participation by the private sector. Fifth, improved public transport services would enhance access to job opportunities for all residents, but especially for low-income residents in the outlying districts, and therefore would result in improving living conditions for the population. Sixth, improved operational practices, better scheduling and routing would encourage a more balanced modal shift.

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Urban Transport Project is to improve, on a sustainable basis, the efficiency and effectiveness of urban transport operations in the municipalities of Ashghabat, Mary, and Chardjou. Specifically, the investments will: (1) reform management of the agencies in charge of urban transport operations in the three participating cities; (2) establish a metropolitan transport organization (APAPO) responsible for the overall management of bus operations; (3) improve cost recovery of the operating enterprises; (4) implement an Operations Improvement Plan; (5) augment and preserve supply of bus services; (6) enhance private sector participation in the provision of urban transport services; and (7) establish a continuing process of public consultation. The project consists of the following components: (1) the purchase of diesel buses, electric trolley buses, and a mobile charging unit and equipment for diesel buses for the three cities mentioned above; (2) rehabilitation of these vehicles to include minibuses and spare parts replacement, workshop, computers, and other tools and equipment for bus operating companies, operating costs coverage, and establishment of APAPO; and (3) technical assistance and training for APAPO, municipal governments, and staff.
